title: Moving day
description: The genetic epidemiology group joins the Department of Congenital Disorders at Statens Serum Institut.
contents: Our research group has moved to the Department of Congenital Disorders within Statens Serum Institut at the beginning of 2025. This move will strengthen ‚Äôomics-based epidemiological research in the Early Life Health strategic research area of SSI. We are excited to be working closely with department head Mette Nyegaard and her team on research into pregnancy and childhood diseases ü§∞üå± At the same time, we are grateful for having been part of a unique environment at the Dept. of Epidemiology Research also at Statens Serum Institut with fantastic colleagues and projects throughout the years.

title: Placenta weight study
description: First GWAS of placental weight published in Nature Genetics
contents:
A well-functioning placenta is essential for fetal and maternal health throughout pregnancy. Using placental weight as a proxy for placental growth, we together with colleagues in the Early Growth Genetics Consortium have conducted the first GWAS of placental weight. The manuscript ‚ÄúGenome-wide association study of placental weight identifies distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth‚Äù is now published in Nature Genetics.
The findings of the study include 40 independent association signals, most of which have an effect through the fetal genome. We found a partial overlap with known birth weight loci, but 12 loci were predominantly or only related to placental weight. These loci harbour genes with connections to placental development and function. We also observed a maternal parent-of-origin effect near KCNQ1. Moreover, we found that fetal genetically mediated higher PW raises preeclampsia risk and shortens gestational duration, and we demonstrated a role for fetal insulin in regulating placental growth.
P√•l Nj√∏lstad, Rachel Freathy, and Bjarke also wrote an accompanying Research Briefing.
Here‚Äôs a summary of the study in Danish and English.
The research was partially funded by the Independent Research Fund Denmark and the Novo Nordisk Foundation.

title: Join our group!
description: Postdoc in the genetics of febrile seizures and epilepsy.
contents:
Are you interested in taking our research in the genetics of seizures to the next level?
We now have an opening for a 2-year fully funded postdoc position in a collaborative setup between the Biobank Unit at Copenhagen University Hospital and Statens Serum Institut, home of the Danish National Biobank. You will work with the world‚Äôs largest genetic data sets on febrile seizures to discover genetic variation associated with this common childhood disease and understand the connections to epilepsy genetics.
You can read much more about the position and our group in the full job ad. Feel free to get in touch for further information about the position.
Genetics of febrile seizures and the similarities and differences with epilepsy genetics is one of our core research areas. Some of our previous work is described here.

title: Job opening in preeclampsia research
description: Postdoc in proteomic and metabolomic analyses of preeclampsia.
contents:
In collaboration with senior researcher, group leader Heather Boyd at Statens Serum Institut, we have an opening for a 2-year fully funded postdoc position. You will help us harness proteomic and metabolomic profiles to improve personalized medicine in women who had preeclampsia, by identifying signatures that predict risk of cardiovascular disease in these women.
You can read much more about the position in the full job ad. Feel free to get in touch for further information about the position.

title: Genetics of pregnancy duration
description: Paper published: Maternal GWAS of gestational duration and preterm birth.
contents:
As part of our long-standing research into genetics of pregnancy outcomes, we contributed to the new international GWAS meta-analysis of gestational duration and preterm birth. The study included analyses of almost 200,000 women and detected 22 loci (16 novel) associated with gestational duration and revealed complex links to birth weight genetics.
The article Genetic effects on the timing of parturition and links to fetal birth weight was published in Nature Genetics on 3 April 2023.

title: Future lab member?
description: Feel free to get in touch!
contents: Although we have no open positions right now, we are always interested in connecting with motivated students and postdocs, so feel free to get in touch if you are interested in joining our lab!

title: Danish National Birth Cohort management
description: Bjarke joins the DNBC scientific management group.
contents: The Danish National Birth Cohort (DNBC) was established in the late 1990‚Äôs with the aim to to recruit 100,000 women early in pregnancy, and to continue follow-up for decades. We have worked extensively with data and biological samples from the DNBC and now Bjarke has joined the DNBC scientific management group to help further develop this unique resource for research.

title: Preprint: GWAS of placental weight
contents: The placenta is a remarkable transient organ of pregnancy. With colleagues in the Early Growth Genetics Consortium, we have conducted the first GWAS of placental weight. The manuscript ‚ÄúGenome-wide association study of placental weight in 179,025 children and parents reveals distinct and shared genetic influences between placental and fetal growth‚Äù is available in preprint.

title: Hernia
contents:
Hernias are characterized by protrusion of an organ or tissue through
its surrounding cavity and often requires surgery.
We performed genome-wide association study (GWAS) scans on 65,492
cases of five different types of hernia and two combined groups against
controls without a history of any hernia in UK Biobank data. The initial
findings for inguinal hernia were followed up in 23,803 additional cases
in cohorts from Finland, Estonia and Denmark.
Here‚Äôs a summary of the study in Danish
and English.
The article ‚ÄúComprehensive
genome-wide association study of different forms of hernia identifies
more than 80 associated loci‚Äù was published in Nature Communications
on June 9th 2022.

title: Largest GWAS of febrile seizures
description: Paper published! Variants in fever response genes and genes for nerve cell signalling associate with febrile seizures.
contents:
Discovery
of genetic variants linked to febrile seizures
It is usually an unexpected and frightening experience for parents
when their child has a febrile seizure. Occurring in 3-5% of infants
febrile seizures are the most common type of abnormal brain activity
during childhood. We led a large-scale GWAS in collaboration with other
research groups in Denmark and Australia and identified seven novel
regions of the genome linked to febrile seizures in the largest genetic
study reported for this common childhood disorder.
Here‚Äôs a summary of the study in Danish
and English.
The research is supported by an Ascending Investigator grant from the
Lundbeck Foundation, who have also written about our research in Danish
and English.
The article ‚ÄúGenome-wide
association study of febrile seizures implicates fever response and
neuronal excitability genes‚Äù was published in Brain on 12 January
2022.
